title: About
text: This is Anthony Rubek’s sports blog. Anthony is an assistant sports editor for the Daily Nebraskan and covers Husker football and men’s basketball.

title: How bad is this year’s NBA rookie class from previous seasons?
text:
This season’s NBA rookie class is widely considered one of the weakest in recent memory. With previous years drafts highlighted by the likes of Victor Wembanyama and Paolo Banchero, the 2024 class lacked the big-name value.
The top two picks — Zaccharie Risacher and Alex Sarr — were rather unknown to a majority of fans despite coming from France like Wembanyama. The batch of college athletes was also underwhelming with guys like Reed Sheppard and Donovan Clingan having upside, but not being worthy of the No. 1 pick.
However, now that these rookies are a few months into their NBA careers, it is worth seeing how they stack up compared to previous classes.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(ggrepel)


Let’s first look at scoring. How do the 2024 rookies fare against the 2023 and 2022 players in their first years? We are able to find out by using their points per game and field goal percentage.


Code
Rookies25 <- read_csv("2425rookies.csv")

Rookies24 <- read_csv("2324rookies.csv")

Rookies23 <- read_csv("2223rookies.csv")

Scoring24 <- Rookies24 |> 
  filter(PTSPG > 7)

Scoring25 <- Rookies25 |> 
  filter(PTSPG > 7)

Scoring23 <- Rookies23 |> 
  filter(PTSPG > 7)

totalscoring <- rbind(Scoring23, Scoring24, Scoring25)

Rookiesnew <- totalscoring |>
  filter(Player == "Jared McCain" |
    Player == "Jaylen Wells" |
    Player == "Dalton Knecht" |
    Player == "Zaccharie Risacher" |
    Player == "Stephon Castle" |
    Player == "Zach Edey" |
    Player == "Alex Sarr" |
    Player == "Yves Missi" |
    Player == "Carlton Carrington" |
    Player == "Kyshawn George" |
    Player == "Tristan Da Silva" |
    Player == "Kyle Filipowski")

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data = totalscoring, aes(x = `FG%`, y = PTSPG), color = "black") + 
  geom_point(data = Rookiesnew, aes(x = `FG%`, y = PTSPG), color = "red")  +
  geom_text_repel(
    data = Rookiesnew,
    aes(x = `FG%`, y = PTSPG, label = Player),
    color = "black"
   )  + theme_minimal() +
  labs(y = "Points per Game",
       x = "Field Goal Percentage",
       title = "The 2024 rookie class is struggling out of the gate compared to previous years.",
       subtitle = "Only 12 players so far averaging over 7 points per game with half shooting under 45%.",
       caption="Source: Basketball Reference | By Anthony Rubek") +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )









So far, the new kids on the block are struggling to get out of the gate. Of the seven points per game minimum to make this chart, only 12 players from this season qualify compared to 20 in 2023 and 22 in 2022 CHECK. Half of the 2024 players are also not shooting efficiently, hovering around the 40% range. Of the rookies, only Philadelphia’s Jared McCain is averaging over 14 points per game.
Another thing to look at is the amount of time the rookies are on the court. The better they are, the more they will play regardless of age.


Code
minutes25 <- read_csv("2425rookies.csv") |> 
  filter(G > 9)

minutes24 <- read_csv("2324rookies.csv") |> 
  filter(G > 32)

minutes23 <- read_csv("2223rookies.csv") |> 
  filter(G > 32)
  
minutes22 <- read_csv("2122rookies.csv") |> 
  filter(G > 32)

rookiemeanminutes <- read_csv("newnewmeanminutes.csv")

ggplot(rookiemeanminutes, aes(x = year, y = mean_minutes)) + 
  geom_line() +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 25)
  ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
    labs(y = "Average Minutes per Game by Rookies",
       x = "Year",
       title = "The 2024 rookie class doesn't see the court",
       subtitle = "This years rookies play just over 16 minutes per game while the previous four classes played over 19 minutes per game.",
       caption="Source: Basketball Reference | By Anthony Rubek") +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )









The last four rookie classes had nearly identical average minutes per game with all coming around the 19 minute range. However, this years class sees a deep fall off to just over 16 minutes per game. While there is a lot of time for this number to change, it doesn’t look promising as the chart only uses players who have appeared in at least 40% of their teams games, no matter the year.
Finally, let’s do a deep dive on this years top rookies compared to last years.


Code
rookies24topscorers <- read_csv("2425rookies.csv") |> 
  filter((Player == "Jared McCain" |
    Player == "Jaylen Wells" |
    Player == "Dalton Knecht" |
    Player == "Zaccharie Risacher" |
    Player == "Stephon Castle"))

rookies23topscorers <- read_csv("2324rookies.csv") |> 
  filter((Player == "Victor Wembanyama" |
    Player == "Brandon Miller" |
    Player == "Keyonte George" |
    Player == "GG Jackson II" |
    Player == "Scoot Henderson"))

rookiescores <- rbind(rookies24topscorers, rookies23topscorers)

rookiescorers <- rookiescores |> 
  select(
    Player,
    PTSPG,
    ASTPG,
    TRBPG
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    Sum = PTSPG + ASTPG + TRBPG 
  ) |> 
  arrange(desc(Sum))

rookiescorers |> gt() |>
  cols_label(
    PTSPG = "Points per game",
    ASTPG = "Assists per game",
    TRBPG = "Rebounds per game",
    Sum = "Sum") |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Last year's rookies outplaying this year's",
    subtitle = "Of the top five scorers of each class, only McCain ranks with the 2023 guys."
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |> 
   tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Anthony Rubek  |  **Source:** Basketball Reference") 
  )  |> 
  tab_style(
    locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
    style = list(
      cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
      cell_text(weight = "bold", size = 12)
    )
  ) |> 
    opt_row_striping() |> 
    tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#E03A3E"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Player == "Jared McCain"
    ) ) |> 
      opt_row_striping() |> 
    tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#E03A3E"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Player == "Stephon Castle"
  ) ) |> 
  opt_row_striping() |> 
    tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#E03A3E"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Player == "Zaccharie Risacher"
    )) |> 
  opt_row_striping() |> 
    tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#E03A3E"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Player == "Jaylen Wells"
    ) ) |> 
  opt_row_striping() |> 
    tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#E03A3E"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Player == "Dalton Knecht"
    ) )















Last year's rookies outplaying this year's


Of the top five scorers of each class, only McCain ranks with the 2023 guys.

By: Anthony Rubek | Source: Basketball Reference








Using the top five leading scorers from both classes and adding their points per game, rebounds per game, and assists per game together, 2023 nearly sweeps the 2024. McCain is the only player to disrupt the table while the other four rookies are at least two points below the rest in the sum.
Overall, the 2024 rookie class is living up to the expectations of being considered one of the worst in NBA history. However, there is still a lot of time for these players especially McCain to develop and eventually turn into star. After all, the 2013 NBA rookie class was once thought of to be on the worst ever, only for Giannis Antetokounmpo to come out of it.

title: Trae Young is underrated by the media
text:
Atlanta Hawks point guard Trae Young is an established star in the NBA. This past season, he averaged 25.7 points per game and a career-high 10.8 assists per game. His play also earned in a spot in the NBA All Star Game.
However, when big media outlets yearly top 100 NBA player lists came out this past summer, Young found himself placed lower than his stats suggest. ESPN had Young at No. 37 on its ranking while CBS had him at No. 35. Both lists had him as the 12th ranked point guard, placing him behind the following: Dallas’ Luka Dončić, Golden State’s Stephen Curry, New York’s Jalen Brunson, Milwaukee’s Damian Lillard, Indiana’s Tyrese Haliburton, Memphis’ Ja Morant, Philadelphia’s Tyrese Maxey, Denver’s Jamal Murray, Sacramento’s De’Aaron Fox, Dallas’ Kyrie Irving, and Boston’s Jrue Holiday.
Looking over key statistics from the 2023-24 season as well as the early results of the 2024-25 campaign, it is easy to tell that Young is greatly underrated by the media.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(ggrepel)
library(scales)
library(gt)


Young’s most known trait has been his passing. Ever since he entered the league in 2018, Young has been near the top of the league in assists. This didn’t change last season, despite him missing time.


Code
NBA23total <- read_csv("NBAtotals2324.csv")

TraeYoung <- NBA23total |>
  filter(Player == "Trae Young")

ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data = NBA23total, aes(x = G, y = AST), color = "black") + 
  geom_point(data = TraeYoung, aes(x = G, y = AST), color = "#E03A3E") + 
  geom_text_repel(
    data = TraeYoung,
    aes(x = G, y = AST, label = Player),
    color = "black"
   ) + theme_minimal() +
  labs(y = "Total Assists",
       x = "Games Played",
       title = "Trae Young passes the ball like no other",
       subtitle = "Despite playing in only 54 games, Young still finished in the top 10 in total assists.",
       caption="Source: Basketball Reference | By Anthony Rubek") +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )


Warning: Removed 1 row containing missing values or values outside the scale range
(`geom_point()`).









Young’s 583 assists put him at eighth in the league. He would have finished even higher if he had played all 82 games.
What about defense? By far the biggest knock on the three-time all star’s game has been his defending. However, Young has improved a lot over time with his steals per game showing that.


Code
nba2324 <- read_csv("NBApergame2324.csv")

nba2324G <- nba2324 |> 
  filter(
    G >= 50
  )

Trae <- nba2324G |>
  filter(Player == "Trae Young")

ggplot() +
  geom_beeswarm(
    data = nba2324G,
    aes(x = Pos, y = STL),
    color = "grey"
  ) +
  geom_beeswarm(
    data = Trae,
    aes(x = Pos, y = STL),
    color = "#E03A3E"
  ) + geom_text_repel(
    data = Trae,
    aes(x = Pos, y = STL, label = Player),
    color = "black") +
  labs(x = "Position",
       y = "Steals per Game",
       title = "Trae Young is a pest on defense",
       subtitle = "The Hawks point guard was one of the better players at his position when it came to steals per game.",
       caption = "Source: Basketball Reference | By Anthony Rubek"
       ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    )









Young’s 1.3 steals per game put at 10th of all point guards, ahead of everyone ranked above him except for Luka Dončić (1.4 SPG) and De’Aaron Fox (2.0 SPG).
The top 100 players lists came out before the regular season started, serving as a prediction of who will be the best this coming year. Three weeks in, we can see how Young fares compared to the 12 point guards ranked above him.


Code
NBA25 <- read_csv("NBApergame2425.csv")

nbapointguards <- NBA25 |> 
  filter(
    Player == "Trae Young" |
    Player == "Jamal Murray" |
    Player == "Jrue Holiday" |
    Player == "De'Aaron Fox" |
    Player == "Damian Lillard" |
    Player == "Kyrie Irving" |
    Player == "Tyrese Maxey" |
    Player == "Tyrese Haliburton" |
    Player == "Ja Morant" |
    Player == "Jalen Brunson" |
    Player == "Stephen Curry" |
    Player == "Luka Dončić")

nbapointguardsnew <- nbapointguards |> 
  select(
    Player,
    PTS,
    AST
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    TotalPointsandAssists = PTS + AST
  ) |> 
  arrange(desc(TotalPointsandAssists))

nbapointguardsnew |>
  gt() |>
  cols_label(
    PTS = "Points per game",
    AST = "Assists per game",
    TotalPointsandAssists = "Total points and assists per game"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Trae Young stacks up well against fellow point guards",
    subtitle = "After three weeks, the star player for the Hawks is ahead of all but one of the point guards ranked above him in preseason top 100 lists."
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |> 
   tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Anthony Rubek  |  **Source:** Basketball Reference") 
  ) |> 
  tab_style(
    locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
    style = list(
      cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
      cell_text(weight = "bold", size = 12)
    )
  ) |> 
    opt_row_striping() |>
  opt_table_lines("none") |> 
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#E03A3E"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Player == "Trae Young"
    )
  )














Trae Young stacks up well against fellow point guards


After three weeks, the star player for the Hawks is ahead of all but one of the point guards ranked above him in preseason top 100 lists.

By: Anthony Rubek | Source: Basketball Reference








Young has exceeded projections so far, leading all point guards in assists per game while coming in at sixth in points per game. It is clear that Young should not have been ranked around the range of guys like Jrue Holiday (No. 36 ESPN, No. 32 CBS) and Jamal Murray (No. 31 ESPN, No. 34 CBS). Instead, Young should have been in discussions with the top of the list like Luka Dončić (No. 2 ESPN, No. 3 CBS).
With a whole season ahead of him, Young has the opportunity to prove the naysayers wrong. If he keeps up the play he is at right now, expect a higher ranking in next years top 100 lists.
